Award.AwardTitle: NetSE: Large: Collaborative Research: Contagion in Large Socio-Communication Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Simple contagion processes underlie various phenomena on complex networks, such as the spread of diseases on social-contact networks and information in communication networks; understanding their dynamics and developing control mechanisms are key issues in numerous applications. The goals of this proposal are: (i) Developing methods to construct synthetic relational networks using partial and noisy data; (ii) Understanding the structure of these networks and the contagion processes, and especially important network properties and typical patterns that have an impact on the dynamics of contagion; (iii) Developing techniques to control the spread of contagion processes, and to detect, prevent and arrest cascading failures in coupled socio-technical networks; and (iv) Understanding the co-evolution between the networks and dynamics, and using this to refine their models, and the strategies to control them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The spread of opinions, attitudes, beliefs, worms in social and communication networks – any actual or virtual contagion transmitted in biological, social, organizational, computing and communication networks is a well-known complex problem. "Contagion" (or diffusion) is used here to mean transmitted phenomena such as diseases, opinions, fads, trends, norms etc.

The spread of infectious diseases through social-contact networks is a major example of an undesirable form of contagion. We have studied, among other aspects, how to optimally protect essential subpopulations (such as emergency workers) during a disease outbreak, by sequestering them, effectively isolating them into groups. We have also studied how to estimate how resilient networks will remain in the face of contagions. More generally, random processes are key to modeling contagion, and this research has naturally led to the further understanding of some fundamental classes of such processes.

Our research here has further shown that structural balance is a basic phenomenon that can well-explain how opinions change over time in a social network. Our work on structural balance sheds a new rigorous light on conflict resolution; we hope this can add to the growing suite of computational tools in sociology.  

Natural sources for the diffusion of ideas, news, and opinions in our world are open-source indicators including tweets, blog-posts, and the news media. This project supported, in part, our work on a large inter-disciplinary project relating to an always-on tool known as EMBERS which digests the output of multiple such sources, and helps predict civil-unrest events.

Four PhD students have received rigorous training in research, as well as research-dissemination skills, through this project. One of these students completed his PhD dissertation in 2015. The insights gained from this project have also helped us mentor a team of undergraduates and two high-school students.
